summary.seg: This manuscript, copied in England at various dates around 1632-1650, contains a selection of Patristic and Byzantine theological texts. The longest of these is the Capita centum de perfectione spirituali of the 5th-century ascetic and bishop Diadochos of Photike. The other contents include excerpts and short texts by writers including prominent Church Fathers such as Maximos the Confessor and Gregory of Nazianzus, along with the 10th-11th-century Byzantine mystic Symeon the New Theologian and more obscure writers such as John of Karpathos and Mark the Hermit.

The manuscript appears to be composed of three physical components bound together, while texts within individual parts were evidently copied at different times, as a number of these are followed by colophons dating the copying of a given work. These variously date the compilation of particular texts to 1632, 1634, 1638, 1639, 1641 and 1650. Some texts are in the hand of the scholar and royal librarian Patrick Young, who owned, copied, commissioned and annotated numerous Greek manuscripts. Young probably also paid for the copying of the other portions. Some of the colophons also give information on the location where the copying of particular texts occurred, variously in London, Oxford and Sherborne, or on the source manuscript employed.

supportDesc.foliation: The manuscript is foliated with the numbers [a-c] + i-iv (pagination) + [1-3], 4-66, 126-172, 174-231, [232] + [d]; ff. 4-66 are paginated in Arabic numerals, in brown ink, recto, upper right and verso, upper left, with the numbers 1-126; this sequence then switches, apparently due to misunderstanding, to foliation for ff. 126-231. There is a gap in the foliation between ff. 172 and 174 due to the loss of the intervening folio, presumably since the manuscript was foliated.
pp. i-iv and ff. [1-3] are paginated with the numbers i-x in Roman numerals, in pencil, recto, upper right.

ff. 4-66 are foliated with the numbers 4-66 in Arabic numerals, in pencil, recto, upper right, often very faint. This sequence treats pp. i-iv as endleaves and omits them, but includes ff. [1-3], though it appears that no numbers of this sequence were ever written on these folios. This sequence has been followed for the purposes of this description.
supportDesc.condition: There is mild water damage, and areas of dirt.

binding.p: 18th-century binding with grey paper covering over couched-laminate boards, with a white parchment spine and plain pastedowns. The classmark appears on the spine on patches.
binding.condition: Some of the covering material from the spine has been lost.

history.provenance: Owned by the antiquary Thomas Gale (c. 1635-1702) Gale, Thomas, 1635?-1702 , Fellow of Trinity and Dean of York. It appears in the 1697 catalogue of Gale's collection contained in Trinity College MS O.5.38 (pp. 158-159).
history.acquisition: Donated by Thomas's son, the antiquary Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744 , in 1738.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

monogr.title: The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College: a descriptive catalogue

series.title: Codices manuscripti Rijksuniversiteit te Leiden. Bibliotheek

msItem.title: List of the first ten Capita of Diadochos
msItem.filiation: Copied from a manuscript at Sion College, London

msItem.author: Symeon, the New Theologian (949-1022)
msItem.title: Catechesis
msItem.note: Often erroneously attributed, as here, to Diadochos of Photike.

msItem.author: Mark the Hermit (d. c. 430)
msItem.title: Opusculum IX De ieiunio
msItem.filiation: This text was copied from a manuscript at Sion College, London.
msItem.colophon: f. 133v Londini in aedibus meis iuxta palatinum Divi Iacobi, 14 Aprili 1641

support.material: pp. i-ii Western paper, no watermark present.

pp. iii-iv, ff. [1-3] Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Pot ( c. 70 30 ) in the gutter.

ff. 4-31, 60-63, 127-134 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Uncertain ( c. 31 c. 31 ) in the gutter.

ff. 32-43 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Pot ( c. 70 30 ) in the gutter, comparable but not identical to Heawood 3611, 3624. These examples are dated to c. 1623-c. 1630.

ff. 44-59 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Grapes ( c. 60 29 ) in the gutter, similar to Heawood 2179. This example is dated to 1638.

ff. 64-66, 126 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Pillar ( c. 50 32 ) in the gutter.

collation.p: This part consists of 19 quires, all binia.

list.item: Quire 14+1 pp. i-iv, ff. [1-3] An additional leaf has been adhered to the beginning of this quire.

layoutDesc.layout: p. iii A single column of 29 lines. 166 125
ff. [1]r-66r A single column of 21-25 lines. 154-179 120
ff. 126r-133v A single column of 15 lines. 177-182 115

handNote.p: ff. [1]r-66r, 228r-231r were copied by Hand A in mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in brown ink, with little variation in letter size. There are deletions by expunctuation and strikethrough.

Syllabic abbreviations are rare but appear throughout the line. Superscript word endings are not in use. Breathings are round, and mute iota is subscript. Use of the double dot is functional only. Nomina sacra are often unabbreviated. Accents are sometimes joined to letters.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points, lower comma, question mark and full stop.
ff. 126r-227v were copied by Patrick Young (Hand B) in mixed minuscule script, in brown ink, slanting slightly to the right.
Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings are not in use. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. Nomina sacra are unabbreviated. Accents are sometimes joined to letters.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower comma, question mark and full stop.
Headings are sometimes written in the same style in red ink.

additions.p: On p. i there are notes regarding Diadochos. The former classmark C. 47 and the number 178 have also been marked here.
On ff. 126r and 132v are notes by Patrick Young regarding the source manuscript of the texts beginning here, and notes by a later hand giving page references.
There are occasional brief marginal annotations in Greek (e.g. f. 53r).

history.origin: This part of the manuscript was copied in England, for and in part by Patrick Young at dates around 23 August 1638 (date of the completion of the text ending on f. 132r, copied in Oxford) and 16 April 1641 (date of the completion of the text ending on f. 133v, copied in London, at Patrick Young's house near the Palace of St James), as indicated by colophons at those points.

msItem.author: John of Karpathos
msItem.title: Capita theologica et gnostica
msItem.filiation: Ths text was copied from a manuscript at Sion College, London.

msItem.author: Mark the Hermit (d. c. 430)
msItem.title: Opusculum X De Melchisidek
msItem.colophon: f. 169r Sherbornae in Juniano nostro, pridie Calendis Augusti MDCXXXIIII

msItem.author: Mark, abbot
msItem.title: On virtues and vices
msItem.filiation: This text was probably copied from Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Barocci 133, ff. 174r-175v.
msItem.note: This text is also found in Mount Athos, Monastery of Xenophon, MS 36 (738), item 26 and Vienna, Österreichische Nationalbibliothek, MS hist. gr. 84, ff. 122v-123r, as well as Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Barocci 133

support.material:
ff. 135-158, 161-162, 164, 167, 169-172 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Flower ( c. 20 20 ) in the gutter.

ff. 159-160, 163, 165-166, 168 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Uncertain ( c. 30 55 ) in the gutter.

collation.p: This part consists of 8 quires, of which one is a single bifolio, four are binia, one is a ternion and two are quaternia.

list.item: Quire 216-1 ff. 143-147 The first folio has been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 274-1 ff. 170-172 The last folio has been lost, apparently without loss of text.

layoutDesc.layout: ff. 135-172 A single column of 32-43 lines. 187-200 125

handNote.p: ff. 126r-227v were copied by Patrick Young (Hand B) in mixed minuscule script, in brown ink, slanting slightly to the right.
Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings are not in use. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. Nomina sacra are unabbreviated. Accents are sometimes joined to letters.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower comma, question mark and full stop.
Headings are sometimes written in the same style in red ink.

physDesc.additions: There are occasional brief marginal notes in Greek and Latin by Patrick Young (e.g. ff. 142v, 148v), and by later hands (e.g. f. 166r).

history.origin: This part of the manuscript was copied by Patrick Young at dates around 31 July 1634 (date of the completion of the text ending on f. 169r, copied at a Young family property in Sherborne) and 10 December 1632 (date of the completion of the text ending on f. 172r, copied in Oxford), as indicated by colophons at those points.

msItem.author: Theodore of Stoudion (759-826)
msItem.title: In adorationem pretiosae et vivisicae crucis media Quadragesima
Theological treatise
msItem.note: Attributed here to Symeon the New Theologian (949-1022)

msItem.author: Theodore of Edessa
msItem.title: Theological chapters
msItem.note: This text is also found in Mount Athos, Monastery of Agios Demetrios, MS 13, ff. 155r-164v

support.material:
ff. 174-177 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Pot ( c. 85 30 ) in the gutter.

ff. 178-[232] Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Pillar ( c. 60 47 ) in the gutter, comparable but not identical to Heawood 3492. This example is dated to 1640.

collation.p: This part consists of 18 quires, of which six are single bifolios and the rest are binia.

list.item:
Quire 454-1
ff. 230-[232] The last folio has been lost, without loss of text.

layoutDesc.layout: ff. 174r-179v, 183r-224r A single column of 31-50 lines. 167-192 120-130

handNote.p: ff. [1]r-133v, ff. 174r-227v were copied by Patrick Young (Hand B) in mixed minuscule script, in brown ink, slanting slightly to the right.
Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings are not in use. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. Accents are sometimes joined to letters.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower comma, question mark and full stop.
Headings are sometimes written in the same style in red ink.

ff. [1]r-66r, 228r-231r were copied by Hand A in mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in brown ink, with little variation in letter size. There are deletions by expunctuation and strikethrough.

Syllabic abbreviations are rare but appear throughout the line. Superscript word endings are not in use. Breathings are round, and mute iota is subscript. Use of the double dot is functional only. Nomina sacra are often unabbreviated. Accents are sometimes joined to letters.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points, lower comma, question mark and full stop.

physDesc.additions: There are occasional brief marginal notes in Greek and Latin by Patrick Young (e.g. ff. 212v, 226r), and by later hands (e.g. f. 203r).

history.origin: This part of the manuscript was copied for and in part by Patrick Young at dates around 17 January 1639 (date of the completion of the text ending on f. 177v) and 19 August 1650 (date of the completion of the text ending on f. 203r, copied in Oxford), as indicated by colophons at those points.
